HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1926

NO PARADE
BEFORE GAME
There will be no parade of
the freshmen before the Maryland game, according to "Bill"
Rodgers, head cheer leader.
This action was taken because
of the confusion which usually occurs in the collection of
tickets before the parade
starts.
Each freshman must purchase his own ticket at the
Athletic Office in the Barn
and present it at the stadium
entrance on Thanksgiving
Day.
The Cotillon Club will hold
a dance Thursday night after
the game in the C. E. Hall.
The admission charges will be
$1.50 per couple.

We think that Lang was extremely sensible in not removing
his socks of many colors on such a cold afternoon and we frankly
admit that under similar conditions we would fight also, although
we dislike fighting immensely, unless two other parties are concerned.
Hasn't the "Pep" Committee any regard for the poor, humble
freshman's health, supposedly the greatest thing in life? Doesn't
this committee realize that George Washington's death was the
direct result of his venturing outside without an overcoat on
an extremely cold night? And that was an extremely cold afternoon when Randolph-Macon was played.
Everyone has a certain amount of modesty and really we
can't imagine anything more embarrassing than to sit through a
football game with no socks. Can you?
We really can't understand why such a ballyhoo has been
set up about Burnett since the argument. Was Dempsey hailed as
a hero last September after Tunney had moulded Dempsey's nose
in several positions untried by beauty specialists? Why of course
not! The newspapers were full of headlines such as Tunney
won for the sake of fighting Marines. Why not—Lang for sake
of fighting Freshmen?

Columnist
FRANCIS M. HASBROUCK, '27

Circulation Manager

Associate Editors

HEYWARD E. BOYCE, JR., '27

Anyway, it can never be said that Lang broke Burnett's nose
to spite his (Burnett's) face.

We thoroughly enjoyed the latest edition of the Black and
Blue Jay, especially the work of Henry Jarrett, I. Evans Rodgers
and "Bill" Banks.
The numerous "cuts" by Banks showed a great amount of
versatility and the jokes were 'quite original. We were really
afraid that the Black and Blue Jay would ape the Harvard Lampoon and have a joke something like this: "Are you a Maryland
man ?" "Why, no! I was just kicked by a horse."

As for the book review, we were delighted with the choice
of novels, showing a great improvement over the first publication and we liked the reviews, although we sensed a certain lack
of originality. But, Henry, we do wish that you would spell the
name of the authoress of "Show Boat" F-e-r-b-e-r and not
F-a-r-b-e-r.

"THE MANLY THING"
It was characteristic of Major Garey to refer in a perfectly
matter-of-fact manner to his recent talk regretting the actions of
some of the St. John's students at the football game as the "only
manly thing to do." It was, undoubtedly, the "manly thing," but
we wonder how many college presidents under similar conditions
would have viewed the matter in this light. Out of those who
would have shared his viewpoint a still smaller number could have
handled the situation in so graceful and straightforward a manner.
We are very glad that the talk was made, for taking into
account the long standing athletic relation, the proximity of the
two institutions, and the fact that Major Garey is President of
St. John's, it would be most unfortunate for one or two incidents
to affect traditionally harmonious relations. Those at the Assembly, evidently were of the same opinion, for the cheer for St.
John's which followed the address was sincere.

NO MORE UNCERTAINTY
The joint letter sent to members of faculty by the Student
Council and Omicron Delta Kappa will, we think, serve a very
useful purpose. The Honor System, as we have often said, is
the most cherished possesion of Hopkins undergraduates; as far
as we have .seen every one of them is willing and proud to live up
to it.
Prior to the circulation of the letter, conditions in different
classes varied so much that the most conscientious student had a
hard time knowing exactly what was expected of him. Now,
however, every man has a clear conception of his obligations under
the Honor System.

THE WILL TO WIN
For the past three years Hopkins has met a supposedly
stronger Maryland team on Thanksgiving Day, and played it to
a standstill. Last year we outplayed them from start to finish.
The game day after tomorrow promises to be no exception. The
heavy Maryland team, with a wealth of reserve material, and a
highly successful season including a 15-0 defeat of Yale to its
credit, will find itself confronted with the will to win personified
in Van Orman's fighting eleven.
The team is ready. Throughout the whole season they have
worked with the Maryland game in view. All that is needed is
the whole souled backing of every student. Spirit inspired the
team to change the St. John's game into a rout; and it can give LIF
victory at the Stadium. The team will give its best; the rest is up
to us. Until the final whistle blows we will back them with everything we have. With the game ours for the taking we cannot fail.

LILLIAN TASAMAN

And we think that the next person to pull that joke about
why Gentlemen Prefer Blondes ought to be shot.

As yet nothing has been said of the moral victor of the recent Harvard-Princeton affair. We feel that this distinction should
go to the University of Michigan which, after many fruitless attempts, has succeeded in scheduling a game with Harvard for next
fall. And unless next year's teams of these two universities differ
vastly from the elevens of the present season, we think that Michigan will enjoy another kind of victory again next November.

It seems to us, Fran, that you have been rather severe in dealing with "Pourboire" thusly. Can't you realize that this column
is still in its swaddling clothes trying weekly to shed them? And
that if the support of our colleagues is not obtained where can
we look for encouragement? And still one more question.
Haven't you realized as yet that it is a much simpler proposition
to ruin a column which already boasts of a good reputation, than
to start an entirely new one and make it successful ?

WRITING EXPLAINED

Dr. French Explains Its Working in
Many Alumni bandsmen will be
English Composition Course
present to augment the present
Using the exact words of another
writer in themes and essays without
giving credit is a violation of the
honor system, according to a statement recently made by Dr. John C.
French. Dr. French was recently
asked by the Student Council to
give his opinion regarding the working of the honor system in English
C.omposition I course.
Words and facts in general are
regarded as common stock and may
be used freely by anyone and a student making use of these facts is
guilty of no violation of the honor
system. To use the same order of
facts is permissible also provided
those facts are phrased in the student's own language.
Dr. French warned students
against quoting inaccurately and
against the doubtful practice of
changing one or two words of a
piece of another writer's work in
order to avoid giving credit. It is
only proper of course to give the
name of the author of an interview
when quoting him. The legal rules
regarding copyrights are much
stricter now than formerly and
when necessary the student should
be careful to receive permission to
quote from either the publisher or
the author.

MICE AND FISH KILLED BY SOUND
WAVES IN DR. WOOD'S LABORATORY
"The first observations on the effects upon animals of high frequency sound vibrations of great intensity were made during the war by
Professor Langevin of Paris. Some
of these experiments it was my good
fortune to witness.
"Fish introduced into the tank in
which the sound waves were being
generated were speedily killed. If
the hand were plunged into the
water in front of the plate from
which the vibrations were radiating,
an intolerable pain was felt which
necessitated an immediate withdrawal of the hand from the water. The
pain was quite different from anything I had ever experienced and
appeared to be deep-seated, perhaps
located at the surface of the bones.
"In the New York laboratory, we
tried an experiment on a small
warm-blooded animal, to see
whether the blood corpuscles could
be destroyed within the arteries and
veins of the animal without other
disastrous results.
"The subject of the experiment
was a mouse, swimming about in a
small vessel of water which was immersed in the oil bath above the

Work on crystals producing
sound waves that kill simple organisms and small fish is being carried
on by Dr. Robert W. Wood, professor of experimental physics.
Actual production of the waves
cannot be made in Dr. Wood's laboratory in the Mechanical Engineering building, for they require an
ocillatory electric current that will
make the crystals vibrate 300,000
times a second through the use of
twice as much electrical energy as
is required in large broadcasting stations.
Earlier in the year, however, Dr.
Wood experimented with the new
waves in the private laboratory of
Alfred L. Loomis, a New York
financier.
"These experiments," he explains,
"deal with the extraordinary effects
produced upon living organisms by
high frequency sound waves in
water, vibrations similar to those
which we should obtain if we struck
a large church bell under water with
a. heavy hammer, only of much
higher pitch, so high as to be far beyond the range of audibility, in fact,
more than six octaves above the
highest note on the piano.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 23, 1926

NO PARADE
BEFORE GAME
There will be no parade of
the freshmen before the Maryland game, according to "Bill"
Rodgers, head cheer leader.
This action was taken because
of the confusion which usually occurs in the collection of
tickets before the parade
starts.
Each freshman must purchase his own ticket at the
Athletic Office in the Barn
and present it at the stadium
entrance on Thanksgiving
Day.
The Cotillon Club will hold
a dance Thursday night after
the game in the C. E. Hall.
The admission charges will be
$1.50 per couple.

We think that Lang was extremely sensible in not removing
his socks of many colors on such a cold afternoon and we frankly
admit that under similar conditions we would fight also, although
we dislike fighting immensely, unless two other parties are concerned.
Hasn't the "Pep" Committee any regard for the poor, humble
freshman's health, supposedly the greatest thing in life? Doesn't
this committee realize that George Washington's death was the
direct result of his venturing outside without an overcoat on
an extremely cold night? And that was an extremely cold afternoon when Randolph-Macon was played.
Everyone has a certain amount of modesty and really we
can't imagine anything more embarrassing than to sit through a
football game with no socks. Can you?
We really can't understand why such a ballyhoo has been
set up about Burnett since the argument. Was Dempsey hailed as
a hero last September after Tunney had moulded Dempsey's nose
in several positions untried by beauty specialists? Why of course
not! The newspapers were full of headlines such as Tunney
won for the sake of fighting Marines. Why not—Lang for sake
of fighting Freshmen?

As for the book review, we were delighted with the choice
of novels, showing a great improvement over the first publication and we liked the reviews, although we sensed a certain lack
of originality. But, Henry, we do wish that you would spell the
name of the authoress of "Show Boat" F-e-r-b-e-r and not
F-a-r-b-e-r.

"THE MANLY THING"
It was characteristic of Major Garey to refer in a perfectly
matter-of-fact manner to his recent talk regretting the actions of
some of the St. John's students at the football game as the "only
manly thing to do." It was, undoubtedly, the "manly thing," but
we wonder how many college presidents under similar conditions
would have viewed the matter in this light. Out of those who
would have shared his viewpoint a still smaller number could have
handled the situation in so graceful and straightforward a manner.
We are very glad that the talk was made, for taking into
account the long standing athletic relation, the proximity of the
two institutions, and the fact that Major Garey is President of
St. John's, it would be most unfortunate for one or two incidents
to affect traditionally harmonious relations. Those at the Assembly, evidently were of the same opinion, for the cheer for St.
John's which followed the address was sincere.

NO MORE UNCERTAINTY
The joint letter sent to members of faculty by the Student
Council and Omicron Delta Kappa will, we think, serve a very
useful purpose. The Honor System, as we have often said, is
the most cherished possesion of Hopkins undergraduates; as far
as we have .seen every one of them is willing and proud to live up
to it.
Prior to the circulation of the letter, conditions in different
classes varied so much that the most conscientious student had a
hard time knowing exactly what was expected of him. Now,
however, every man has a clear conception of his obligations under
the Honor System.

THE WILL TO WIN
For the past three years Hopkins has met a supposedly
stronger Maryland team on Thanksgiving Day, and played it to
a standstill. Last year we outplayed them from start to finish.
The game day after tomorrow promises to be no exception. The
heavy Maryland team, with a wealth of reserve material, and a
highly successful season including a 15-0 defeat of Yale to its
credit, will find itself confronted with the will to win personified
in Van Orman's fighting eleven.
The team is ready. Throughout the whole season they have
worked with the Maryland game in view. All that is needed is
the whole souled backing of every student. Spirit inspired the
team to change the St. John's game into a rout; and it can give LIF
victory at the Stadium. The team will give its best; the rest is up
to us. Until the final whistle blows we will back them with everything we have. With the game ours for the taking we cannot fail.

LILLIAN TASAMAN

Using the exact words of another

Words and facts in general are
regarded as common stock and may

system. To use the same order of
facts is permissible also provided
those facts are phrased in the student's own language.
Dr. French warned students
against quoting inaccurately and
against the doubtful practice of
changing one or two words of a
piece of another writer's work in
order to avoid giving credit. It is
only proper of course to give the
name of the author of an interview
when quoting him. The legal rules
regarding copyrights are much
stricter now than formerly and
when necessary the student should
be careful to receive permission to
quote from either the publisher or
the author.

MICE AND FISH KILLED BY SOUND
WAVES IN DR. WOOD'S LABORATORY
"The first observations on the effects upon animals of high frequency sound vibrations of great intensity were made during the war by
Professor Langevin of Paris. Some
of these experiments it was my good
fortune to witness.
"Fish introduced into the tank in
which the sound waves were being
generated were speedily killed. If
the hand were plunged into the
water in front of the plate from
which the vibrations were radiating,
an intolerable pain was felt which
necessitated an immediate withdrawal of the hand from the water. The
pain was quite different from anything I had ever experienced and
appeared to be deep-seated, perhaps
located at the surface of the bones.
"In the New York laboratory, we
tried an experiment on a small
warm-blooded animal, to see
whether the blood corpuscles could
be destroyed within the arteries and
veins of the animal without other
disastrous results.
"The subject of the experiment
was a mouse, swimming about in a
small vessel of water which was immersed in the oil bath above the

Work on crystals producing
sound waves that kill simple organisms and small fish is being carried
on by Dr. Robert W. Wood, professor of experimental physics.
Actual production of the waves
cannot be made in Dr. Wood's laboratory in the Mechanical Engineering building, for they require an
ocillatory electric current that will
make the crystals vibrate 300,000
times a second through the use of
twice as much electrical energy as
is required in large broadcasting stations.
Earlier in the year, however, Dr.
Wood experimented with the new
waves in the private laboratory of
Alfred L. Loomis, a New York
financier.
"These experiments," he explains,
"deal with the extraordinary effects
produced upon living organisms by
high frequency sound waves in
water, vibrations similar to those
which we should obtain if we struck
a large church bell under water with
a. heavy hammer, only of much
higher pitch, so high as to be far beyond the range of audibility, in fact,
more than six octaves above the
highest note on the piano.
